The best way to slow the curve of #COVID19 is through aggressive testing & tracing, as well as continued practice of social distancing. These next few weeks are critical, & it will take all of us doing our part to #StopTheSpread in Oklahoma. (3/3)

I've also lifted some of the restrictions on who can be tested for #COVID19. Our state now has 13,000 test kits available & anyone with symptoms or whose been in direct contact with someone diagnosed needs to be tested. (2/3)

America‚Äôs supply chain remains effective and intact. The president wanted me to let Oklahoma know there will be no disruption to the supply chain. There is no need to stock up on critical supplies.
I‚Äôve cut restrictions on truck drivers and commercial vehicles so they can effectively respond and transport medical supplies and other things that are critically needed.

I‚Äôve cut regulations on telemedicine, making it easier for you to see a doctor without leaving home. This order also allows health care professionals like doctors and nurses who are licensed in another state to get a temporary license to practice here.

I‚Äôm requiring all hospitals, medical clinics, and private testing labs to report accurate data to the state health department every day regarding their capacity to take new patients, their equipment supplies, and testing results.
Today, I am also issuing a second Executive Order suspending many state regulations that could be a barrier to quickly and proactively reduce the threat of #COVID19

As Governor, I urge Oklahomans to consider curbside pickup and delivery from your favorite restaurants. We need our job creators to get creative during this challenging time, and we must also critically balance protecting public health during this 15-day window.
On Monday, I spoke to restaurant owners across the state of Oklahoma. This is going to cause a great upheaval for hardworking Oklahomans, many who depend on these hourly-wage jobs.

At 10 AM on Monday, our state agencies began implementing telework policies to limit face-to-face contact. I‚Äòm encouraging Oklahoma businesses to quickly mobilize and innovate to limit professional gatherings.

I have been constantly holding meetings with our state agency leaders, hospitals, health care professionals, and business owners, determining the best innovative solutions to protect our workers and to mitigate this health issue

On Sept. 17, I had the privilege of selecting Justice John Kane IV out of a list of highly qualified candidates for my first appointment to the State Supreme Court, fulfilling his dream to walk in his great-grandfather‚Äôs footsteps.

One of the greatest honors and blessings of being Governor is getting to be a part of helping other Oklahomans achieve their dreams. That boy I mentioned is today serving as a newly minted Justice on our State Supreme Court.
This boy read all his great-grandfather‚Äôs writings and opinions, and it is what inspired this boy to go to law school at the University of Oklahoma in the late 1980s.

His great grandfather was one of the founders of the state of Oklahoma and a framer of our State Constitution. After statehood, he became one of the first State Supreme Court Justices and served as Chief Justice.
Decades ago, an Oklahoma boy from Pawhuska dreamed about being like his great grandfather. While he had never met his great grandfather, they shared the same name. (1/of a few..)
